tags: a song of ice and fire

summary: in ur opinion is there anyway jonsa could happen that would leave you fully satisfied (or more satisfied) that wouldnt reduce...
question: in ur opinion is there anyway jonsa could happen that would leave you fully satisfied (or more satisfied) that wouldnt reduce her to propping jons character up? i ask cause i dont see jonsa as reducing sansa’s character but i also understand your perspective and reasoning that it would, so i was curious if they could do it in a way you would prefer or if you’d prefer it not at all. no hate, long time jonsa and follower of your blog who loves ur analysis of sansa, my fave got character
answer: If it’s happening, then I want to be a romantic subplot rather than her main plot. I don’t want Sansa to become Talisa where she’s only Jon’s love interest. I want Sansa dealing with displaced people escaping the Night King, I want her agonising over the food shortage issue, I want her finding skilled personnel to help work dragonglass onto weapons, I want her politicking with Varys and Tyrion, I want her having a tense relationship with Dany that in this case would also be a part love triangle, I want her dealing with the antagonism between the different armies. I’m very OK with Sansa protecting Jon when she also has other things going on because Jon will certainly be involved in many subplots.

I’m very OK with Sansa protecting Jon when she also has other things going on because Jon will certainly be involved in many subplots.

summary: [SPOILERS] The Proof is in the pudding.... Somewhere
title: [SPOILERS] The Proof is in the pudding.... Somewhere
body:
So we were told the answers to the ending of GOT can be found in the first book. Tonight I was listening to Tyrions chapter when he is involved in the battle against the Stark force’s at the Trident. I found the description interesting. Most of the descriptive words used were reminding me of other characters in the book. It’s almost as thought you could picture another battle happening.

Then I started thinking about the other battle he was involved in at Kings Landing. I haven’t had an opportunity to review this chapter yet but it did get me thinking. Most people agree that there will be 2 battles in the final season. What if Tyrions previous battles are the key?

Apologies if this is a tired subject and/or a previously suggested idea. I will delete this post if so.



Source: http://bit.ly/2CQKQXs

summary: Go-Jek makes first close of $2 billion round at $9.5 billion valuation
title: Go-Jek makes first close of $2 billion round at $9.5 billion valuation
body:
Southeast Asia-based ridesharing firm Go-Jek is making progress with its plan to raise up to $2 billion in fresh capital to fund its battle with close rival Grab.

Indonesia-headquartered Go-Jek has closed an initial chunk of that round after a collection of existing investors, including Google, Tencent and JD.com, agreed to invest around $920 million toward it, three sources with knowledge of the investment told TechCrunch.

The deal, which we understand could be announced as soon as next week, will value Go-Jek’s business at around $9.5 billion, one source told TechCrunch. With existing investors on board, the company is now actively soliciting checks from other backers to take it to its target. The capital is likely to go toward deepening its presence in new markets and furthering its fintech push.

A Go-Jek representative declined to respond when contacted by TechCrunch for comment on its fundraising efforts.

This incoming round excluded, Go-Jek has raised more than $2 billion from investors to date, including a $1.4 billion round that closed last year and valued its business at $5 billion.

Founded in 2015, Go-Jek began in motorbike taxis before expanding to four-wheels, service on demand and fintech. It decided to go after a $2 billion raise last year — having seen Grab gobble up Uber’s local business in Southeast Asia — but it has taken some time to make progress. That’s partially down to an effort to “clean the cap table” by buying out some early investors and longer-serving or former staff with equity, two sources told TechCrunch.

Likewise, there has also been discussion around including the acquisition of JD.com’s local JD.id business, valued at more than $1 billion, in the deal. As far as we know, a resolution hasn’t been found despite lengthy talks.

An acquisition of JD.id would not only see JD.com’s influence deepen with Go-Jek, but it would give the ride-hailing startup a strong position in Indonesia’s e-commerce space, which includes three other unicorns: Alibaba-owned Lazada, Tokopedia — which is backed by Alibaba and SoftBank’s Vision Fund — and Bukalapak, which also recently raised money for growth.

There is some doubt, however. Speaking to Reuters this week, co-founder Kevin Aluwi denied Go-Jek has plans to enter e-commerce.

Fundraising for Southeast Asia’s ridesharing companies went up a few notches last year after Uber decided to exit the region through a deal with Grab, which saw the U.S. firm pick up a potentially lucrative 27.5 percent stake in Singapore-based Grab.

Grab raised a $3 billion Series H round, anchored by a $1 billion injection from Toyota, but the company plans to increase that fundraising effort to as much as $5 billion, as we reported at the tail end of last year.

Why all the huge checks? At stake is a dominant position within a fast-growing online market.

Ride-hailing in Southeast Asia is poised to grow from an $8 billion annual business in 2018 to $31 billion by 2025, according to a report from Google and Temasek. Indonesia alone is tipped to account for nearly half of that figure.

The report from Google and Temasek forecasts major growth for ride-hailing in Southeast Asia

With a cumulative population of more than 620 million people and increasing internet access, Southeast Asia has emerged from the shadows of China and India to become an attractive market for startups and tech companies. Chinese giants like Tencent and Alibaba have stepped up investment areas in recent years, with e-commerce, fintech and other “ground zero” infrastructure services among their targets as the region begins to turn digital in the same way China has.

That’s where Grab and Go-Jek get interesting because, beyond simply catering to transportation, both companies have expanded to offer services on-demand, like e-groceries, as well as payments and financial services such as loans, remittance and insurance. The goal is to become the region’s one-stop “super app” like WeChat, Alipay and Meituan in China.

So far, Go-Jek has fanned out beyond ride-hailing to offer fintech and other services in Indonesia, but it is still getting to grips with the regional play. It expanded to Vietnam, Thailand and Singapore last year while the Philippines is a work in progress following a setback after it was denied an operating permit earlier this month.

Already, though, it is making plans for the Philippines after it acquired Coins.ph, a fintech startup that is likely to be the base for a local push into payments and financial services. The deal was officially undisclosed, but sources told TechCrunch that Go-Jek has paid around $72 million — that potentially makes it the company’s largest acquisition to date. That shows how serious Go-Jek is both about its expansion efforts and its fintech business.

Go-Jek CEO Nadiem Makarim worked at McKinsey for three years before starting the company [Photographer: Wei Leng Tay/Bloomberg]

In the here and now, Go-Jek claims more than 125 million downloads in Indonesia, more than a million drivers and some 300,000 food merchants. It claims to process 100 million transactions per month, while Aluwi told Reuters that total transactions on its platforms crossed $12.5 billion last year. That doesn’t mean net income, however, as the company takes only a slice of customers’ ridesharing fares and payment volumes.

Grab, meanwhile, operates in eight markets in Southeast Asia. It claims more than 130 million downloads and more than 2.5 billion completed rides to date. Grab is assumed to not yet be profitable, but it has said that it made $1 billion in revenue in 2018. It projects that the figure will double this year.

The company has raised around $6.8 billion from investors, according to data from Crunchbase, and Grab was last valued at $11 billion.

Read more: https://techcrunch.com/2019/01/24/go-jek-valuation-9-5-billion/

The post Go-Jek makes first close of $2 billion round at $9.5 billion valuation appeared first on Viral TV News.



from WordPress http://www.viraltvnews.com/game_of_thrones/go-jek-makes-first-close-of-2-billion-round-at-9-5-billion-valuation/

trail.content:
Southeast Asia-based ridesharing firm Go-Jek is making progress with its plan to raise up to $2 billion in fresh capital to fund its battle with close rival Grab.

Indonesia-headquartered Go-Jek has closed an initial chunk of that round after a collection of existing investors, including Google, Tencent and JD.com, agreed to invest around $920 million toward it, three sources with knowledge of the investment told TechCrunch.

The deal, which we understand could be announced as soon as next week, will value Go-Jek’s business at around $9.5 billion, one source told TechCrunch. With existing investors on board, the company is now actively soliciting checks from other backers to take it to its target. The capital is likely to go toward deepening its presence in new markets and furthering its fintech push.

A Go-Jek representative declined to respond when contacted by TechCrunch for comment on its fundraising efforts.

This incoming round excluded, Go-Jek has raised more than $2 billion from investors to date, including a $1.4 billion round that closed last year and valued its business at $5 billion.

Founded in 2015, Go-Jek began in motorbike taxis before expanding to four-wheels, service on demand and fintech. It decided to go after a $2 billion raise last year — having seen Grab gobble up Uber’s local business in Southeast Asia — but it has taken some time to make progress. That’s partially down to an effort to “clean the cap table” by buying out some early investors and longer-serving or former staff with equity, two sources told TechCrunch.

Likewise, there has also been discussion around including the acquisition of JD.com’s local JD.id business, valued at more than $1 billion, in the deal. As far as we know, a resolution hasn’t been found despite lengthy talks.

An acquisition of JD.id would not only see JD.com’s influence deepen with Go-Jek, but it would give the ride-hailing startup a strong position in Indonesia’s e-commerce space, which includes three other unicorns: Alibaba-owned Lazada, Tokopedia — which is backed by Alibaba and SoftBank’s Vision Fund — and Bukalapak, which also recently raised money for growth.

There is some doubt, however. Speaking to Reuters this week, co-founder Kevin Aluwi denied Go-Jek has plans to enter e-commerce.

Fundraising for Southeast Asia’s ridesharing companies went up a few notches last year after Uber decided to exit the region through a deal with Grab, which saw the U.S. firm pick up a potentially lucrative 27.5 percent stake in Singapore-based Grab.

Grab raised a $3 billion Series H round, anchored by a $1 billion injection from Toyota, but the company plans to increase that fundraising effort to as much as $5 billion, as we reported at the tail end of last year.

Why all the huge checks? At stake is a dominant position within a fast-growing online market.

Ride-hailing in Southeast Asia is poised to grow from an $8 billion annual business in 2018 to $31 billion by 2025, according to a report from Google and Temasek. Indonesia alone is tipped to account for nearly half of that figure.

External image

The report from Google and Temasek forecasts major growth for ride-hailing in Southeast Asia

With a cumulative population of more than 620 million people and increasing internet access, Southeast Asia has emerged from the shadows of China and India to become an attractive market for startups and tech companies. Chinese giants like Tencent and Alibaba have stepped up investment areas in recent years, with e-commerce, fintech and other “ground zero” infrastructure services among their targets as the region begins to turn digital in the same way China has.

That’s where Grab and Go-Jek get interesting because, beyond simply catering to transportation, both companies have expanded to offer services on-demand, like e-groceries, as well as payments and financial services such as loans, remittance and insurance. The goal is to become the region’s one-stop “super app” like WeChat, Alipay and Meituan in China.

So far, Go-Jek has fanned out beyond ride-hailing to offer fintech and other services in Indonesia, but it is still getting to grips with the regional play. It expanded to Vietnam, Thailand and Singapore last year while the Philippines is a work in progress following a setback after it was denied an operating permit earlier this month.

Already, though, it is making plans for the Philippines after it acquired Coins.ph, a fintech startup that is likely to be the base for a local push into payments and financial services. The deal was officially undisclosed, but sources told TechCrunch that Go-Jek has paid around $72 million — that potentially makes it the company’s largest acquisition to date. That shows how serious Go-Jek is both about its expansion efforts and its fintech business.

External image

Go-Jek CEO Nadiem Makarim worked at McKinsey for three years before starting the company [Photographer: Wei Leng Tay/Bloomberg]

In the here and now, Go-Jek claims more than 125 million downloads in Indonesia, more than a million drivers and some 300,000 food merchants. It claims to process 100 million transactions per month, while Aluwi told Reuters that total transactions on its platforms crossed $12.5 billion last year. That doesn’t mean net income, however, as the company takes only a slice of customers’ ridesharing fares and payment volumes.

Grab, meanwhile, operates in eight markets in Southeast Asia. It claims more than 130 million downloads and more than 2.5 billion completed rides to date. Grab is assumed to not yet be profitable, but it has said that it made $1 billion in revenue in 2018. It projects that the figure will double this year.

The company has raised around $6.8 billion from investors, according to data from Crunchbase, and Grab was last valued at $11 billion.

Read more: https://techcrunch.com/2019/01/24/go-jek-valuation-9-5-billion/

The post Go-Jek makes first close of $2 billion round at $9.5 billion valuation appeared first on Viral TV News.

summary: this might be just me, but i dont want Sansa and Arya to only be supporting rolls to Jon. Like i get Jon's yhe typical hero and...
question: this might be just me, but i dont want Sansa and Arya to only be supporting rolls to Jon. Like i get Jon's yhe typical hero and needs to fight the NK but Sansa and Arya are more then just props for Jon. If anything Jon/Arya and Sansa/Bran should pair up for fighting bit it feels like D&D is pushing that only Jon (and Dany) are capable of defeating the NK.
answer: I think they’re pushing Jon harder than everyone but I’m strangely confident that it’ll be Bran who defeats the Night King. I just wish we get a few Sansa subplots rather than entangling her in Jon’s storyline

summary: House Manning is a noble house from the crownlands. According to semi-canon sources they blazon their arms with a red sea lion...
caption:
House Manning is a noble house from the crownlands. According to semi-canon sources they blazon their arms with a red sea lion between two black pallets on white. The aquatic sigil suggests the House may control territory on Blackwater Bay.

​House Manning at the end of the third century

The known Mannings during the timespan of the events described in A Song of Ice and Fire are:

No member has appeared yet.

  • Coat of arms: A red sea lion between two black pallets on white, (Argent, between two pallets sable a sea-lion gules)
  • Region: Crownlands
  • Overlord: House Baratheon of King’s Landing

blog.name: callmejude
blog.title: "NO. YOU MOVE."
blog.description:
I Am: older than you, but younger than your mom; Texan-born Canadian; an ex-English major; a lesbian with celebrity exceptions; awkwardly friendly; subtle like a supernova; damn near impossible to offend; overly excitable; quick to cry; childish as hell; a Gryffindor; a Baratheon; a geek; a nerd; a dweeb; a romantic; and probably more than a little idealistic. I try too hard and don't think enough.

My name is Kelty but I'll answer to just about anything you wanna call me, including and especially dumb personalized pet names or any fictional characters you think I resemble. I'm pretty easy to please.

My icon was Chris Evans for seven years but now it's Theon Greyjoy as drawn by kowada25. Winter has come.

THE PEOPLE YOU SHOULD KNOW (IF YOU WANT TO KNOW ME):

Kendra (my girlfriend) 

Emily (my best friend) 

Bliss (my soul buddy) 

Riot (my bratty little sister)

tags: I'm not a writer I just drink a lot about it
summary: In shipwrecks on the snow, what drives theon to reject jon at first? Does he want to protect jon? Or prevent himself from...
question: In shipwrecks on the snow, what drives theon to reject jon at first? Does he want to protect jon? Or prevent himself from getting more attached to him?
answer:
Yeah, I figure that Theon is, well… Theon. And so he’s very guarded and when he realizes his feelings for Jon might be reciprocated, he tries to distance himself, simply because he doesn’t want to be attached to anything. In canon (of the show, at least) his biggest crush is on Ros, which I figure he probably considers “safe,” because 1) she has to pretend to like him and 2) there’s no commitment there. Theon is very proud but very tender, and developing attachments is probably not something that’s looked upon very highly at all on the Iron Islands. Especially not feelings for one’s captors, which is what the Starks (and to some extent I would assume Theon believes all Northmen) are, and so the thought of being in love with one probably freaks him out a lot. 

So at first he really tries to distance himself from Jon because he doesn’t want to admit to himself that he may actually WANT to stick around in the North for his captor’s bastard son, but, well. Jon is unintentionally very persuasive lmao.

ANOTHER GREAT QUESTION. Man I love getting question asks about my fics this just makes me all GIDDY PLEASE LET ME KNOW ANY MORE QUESTIONS YOU HAVE I LOVE ANSWERING THEM THAT GOES FOR EVERYONE THANK YOU!!!

summary: In summer offerings, if jon ever showed interest in someone else would theon get jealous? Or possessive, Do you think?
question: In summer offerings, if jon ever showed interest in someone else would theon get jealous? Or possessive, Do you think?
answer:
That’s actually a good question! My first instinct would be to say yes. He enjoys sharing with Ros I think mainly because he thinks of her as “just a whore,” but I do think that if Jon were to actually express interest in another person he’d probably get pretty jealous. I love Theon, but he’s a dumb spoiled boy and it gets him into a lot of trouble, so I’d assume he’d probably be a little possessive if Jon ever started getting moony over someone else.

What do you think, actually? That’s a fun question and it’s really open to interpretation so I’m curious to know if you feel differently! :D
